framework.lib
Class State<T extends Point>

java.lang.Object
  framework.lib.State<T>
Type Parameters:
T - Specifies the number of dimensions this state should represent. Should be a strict subclass of Point.
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterable<T>
public class State<T extends Point>
extends Object
implements Iterable<T>

Represents a state of a cellular automaton, supporting an arbitrary number of dimensions. The dimension is specified by the type parameter. It supports any finite size for the length of each axis, but it must be finite. The nth axis goes from 0 to the value of the nth axis of the point specified as the size. It also supports wrapping around (going back to 0 after reaching the end of the axis) on any or all of the axes.

Lets you iterate over all of the points in the state

Author:
Kunal Desai, James Grugett, Prasanth Somasundar

Constructor Detail

State

public State(T size,
             int numStates)
Creates a new State with default no wrapping

Parameters:
size - The bounding point, acts like "array.length".
numStates - The total number of states a cell can be in. For example, Conway's Game of Life has 2 states, alive and dead.

State

public State(T size,
             int numStates,
             boolean[] wraps)
Creates a new State with wrapping as specified by the boolean array. The array is such that if wraps[i] is true, then the ith axis will wrap around.

Parameters:
size - The point farthest from the origin, giving the bounds
numStates - The total number of states a cell can be in. For example, Conway's Game of Life has 2 states, alive and dead.
wraps - A boolean array specifying which axes should wrap around.
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if size.numDimensions() != wraps.length

State

public State(T size,
             int numStates,
             boolean[] wraps,
             HashMap<T,Integer> grid)
Creates a new State with wrapping as specified by the boolean array, and the given initial state. The array is such that if wraps[i] is true, then the ith axis will wrap around. In the HashMap grid, if a point maps to nothing, we assume it has state 0.

Parameters:
size - The point farthest from the origin, giving the bounds
numStates - The total number of states a cell can be in. For example, Conway's Game of Life has 2 states, alive and dead.
wraps - A boolean array specifying which axes should wrap around. Treat a null array as an array of falses.
grid - The initial state.
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if any of the states mapped to in grid are negative, or greater than or equal to numStates or size.numDimensions() != wraps.length
Method Detail

setWraps

public void setWraps(boolean[] wraps)
Allows you to set whether each axis wraps all at once.

Parameters:
wraps - a boolean array where the ith value determines whether the ith axis wraps around. A null array results in no wrapping.
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if wraps.length != the number of dimensions of the state

setWrap

public void setWrap(int dimension,
                    boolean wrap)
Sets whether axis number dimension wraps around or not

Parameters:
dimension - the axis
wrap - true if you want the axis to wrap, false if not
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if dimension is negative or >= the dimension of the state.

getDimension

public int getDimension()
Gets the number of axes this state holds a representation for.

Returns:
the number of dimensions (or the number of axes)

getSize

public T getSize()
Returns the point farthest from the origin that this state can hold. Each of the coordinates of points in this state must have coordinate number i have value between 0 and getSize()'s ith coordinate, inclusive.

Returns:
the farthest point from the origin
Throws:
RuntimeException - if T implements copy incorrectly

setSize

public void setSize(T size)
Sets the size of the state to the given size. If this is larger than the previous size, it will map all new cells to state 0. If it is smaller, all cells outside of the new bounds will be thrown out.

Parameters:
size - the new dimensions of the State

setState

public void setState(HashMap<T,Integer> grid)
Sets the state based on a mapping between T and states (stored as integers).

Parameters:
grid - A mapping of points to states. If grid is null, treat it as an empty grid
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if grid specifies values outside of the size or specifies invalid states

setCellState

public void setCellState(T cell,
                         int state)
Sets the state of the given cell to the given state.

Parameters:
cell - The cell you want to change the state of.
state - the state to which you want to change the cell.
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if cell is not in the bounds of this State, or if state is negative or greater than or equal to the number of allowed states. or if Cell is of the wrong number of dimensions

getCellState

public int getCellState(T cell)
Gets the state of the requested cell.

Parameters:
cell - the coordinates of the requested cell.
Returns:
The state of the requested cell. Defaults to 0 if it was never explicitly stated.
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if cell is not in the bounds of this State

getNeighborhood

public Neighborhood<T> getNeighborhood(T cell,
                                       int radius)
Gets a neighborhood for a given cell, with the given radius. If wrapping is set to false, values outside of the bounds of size have state 0

Parameters:
cell - the cell to center the neighborhood around.
radius - the radius of the neighborhood
Returns:
The requested neighborhood

step

public void step(Rule<T> r)
Steps the world once based on the rules specified in r. This modifies the state in place, but the modification is atomic.

Parameters:
r - the rule used to step the state once.

iterator

public Iterator<T> iterator()
Iterates over all of the Points inside this State.

Specified by:
iterator in interface Iterable<T extends Point>
Returns:
an iterator for the Points inside the State
